messages.text:
do you know how to update, eg.

```function make_constraint(expr::Operation, constraint, var=[])
    C = Contractor(var, expr)
    ex = expr ∈ constraint
    ConstraintSeparator(constraint, C, ex)
end```
i think it's `expr::Term`  but i'm not 100% sure if that covers all relevant cases

messages.text:
```julia> @variables x y
(x, y)

julia> ModelingToolkit.istree(x)
false

julia> ModelingToolkit.istree(x + y)
false

julia> ModelingToolkit.istree(x + y <= 1)
true```

true

messages.text:
cannot the `@constraint` macro from `IntervalConstraintProgramming` handle numerical expressions such as `1/3` `sqrt(3)` and so on?

ERROR: LoadError: TypeError: in Interval, in T, expected T<:Real, got Type{Expr}
Stacktrace:
 [1] ..(::Float64, ::Expr) at C:\Users\lucaa\.julia\packages\IntervalArithmetic\odPjL\src\intervals\intervals.jl:144
 [2] parse_comparison(::Expr) at C:\Users\lucaa\.julia\packages\IntervalConstraintProgramming\CQFKf\src\separator.jl:88
 [3] @constraint(::LineNumberNode, ::Module, ::Expr, ::Any) at C:\Users\lucaa\.julia\packages\IntervalConstraintProgramming\CQFKf\src\separator.jl:185 (repeats 2 times)
in expression starting at REPL[4]:1

attachments.title: TIRA: Toolbox for Interval Reachability Analysis
attachments.text: This paper presents TIRA, a Matlab library gathering several methods for the computation of interval over-approximations of the reachable sets for both continuous- and discrete-time nonlinear...

messages.text: there's also a related tool called PIRK ( <https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7363203/> )

attachments.title: PIRK: Scalable Interval Reachability Analysis for High-Dimensional Nonlinear Systems
attachments.text: Reachability analysis is a critical tool for the formal verification of dynamical systems and the synthesis of controllers for them. Due to their computational complexity, many reachability analysis methods are restricted to systems with relatively small ...

messages.text:
does JuliaIntervals handle solving this? I want the solution space.
```0<m, 0<a, v<0, m < f1(m,a,v), m < f2(m,a,v)


fn1(A,v,m) = (m * (-2*sqrt(m) + sqrt(A^2 + 4*m))) / (A*v^2)
fn2(A,v,m) = (A*m) / (v * (2*sqrt(m) + A*v))```

elements.text: does JuliaIntervals handle solving this? I want the solution space.

messages.text:
I think this is a possible code (from a few months ago; not tested now):
```
inner = paving.inner
boundary = paving.boundary;


## Makie plotting set-up
positions = Point{3, Float32}[Point3(mid(x)...) for x in vcat(inner, boundary)]
scales = Vec3f0[Vec3f0([diam(x) for x in xx]) for xx in vcat(inner, boundary)]

zs = Float32[x[3] for x in positions]
minz = minimum(zs)
maxz = maximum(zs)

xs = Float32[x[1] for x in positions]
minx = minimum(xs)
maxx = maximum(xs)

colors1 = RGBA{Float32}[RGBA( (zs[i]-minz)/(maxz-minz), (xs[i]-minx)/(maxx-minx), 0f0, 0.1f0)
        for i in 1:length(inner)];
colors2 = RGBA{Float32}[RGBA( 0.5f0, 0.5f0, 0.5f0, 0.02f0) for x in boundary];
colors = vcat(colors1, colors2);

## Makie plotting:
cube = Rect{3, Float32}(Vec3f0(-0.5, -0.5, -0.5), Vec3f0(1, 1, 1))
# centre, widths

meshscatter(positions, marker=cube, scale=scales, color=colors, transparency=true)```

elements.text: I think this is a possible code (from a few months ago; not tested now):

inner = paving.inner
boundary = paving.boundary;


## Makie plotting set-up
positions = Point{3, Float32}[Point3(mid(x)...) for x in vcat(inner, boundary)]
scales = Vec3f0[Vec3f0([diam(x) for x in xx]) for xx in vcat(inner, boundary)]

zs = Float32[x[3] for x in positions]
minz = minimum(zs)
maxz = maximum(zs)

xs = Float32[x[1] for x in positions]
minx = minimum(xs)
maxx = maximum(xs)

colors1 = RGBA{Float32}[RGBA( (zs[i]-minz)/(maxz-minz), (xs[i]-minx)/(maxx-minx), 0f0, 0.1f0)
        for i in 1:length(inner)];
colors2 = RGBA{Float32}[RGBA( 0.5f0, 0.5f0, 0.5f0, 0.02f0) for x in boundary];
colors = vcat(colors1, colors2);

## Makie plotting:
cube = Rect{3, Float32}(Vec3f0(-0.5, -0.5, -0.5), Vec3f0(1, 1, 1))
# centre, widths

meshscatter(positions, marker=cube, scale=scales, color=colors, transparency=true)

messages.text:
It is not clear to me that the complement operator `!` when applied to a ratio inequality constraint is safe because `!(a/b > 1)` is not `(b/a > 1)` (likely intended as the opposite relation) rather it is `(a/b <= 1) == (b/a >= 1)` .
An operator that flips the sense of an inequality would be a nice addition.

elements.text: It is not clear to me that the complement operator
when applied to a ratio inequality constraint is safe because
(likely intended as the opposite relation) rather it is

.
An operator that flips the sense of an inequality would be a nice addition.

messages.text: Is there an established result that `(f(x) > g(x))` is better rewritten as `(f(x) - g(x)) > 0` or as `(f(x) / g(x)) > 1` with respect to the numerical stability of the `paving` processes, or are both guaranteed equally strongly?

elements.text: Is there an established result that
with respect to the numerical stability of the
processes, or are both guaranteed equally strongly?

messages.text: That's a silly restriction on the parsing of the constraint. I would write it as f - g > 0, which is how I think it should be rewritten automatically. I hadn't thought about f /g - 1. That seems like a bad idea when g can be zero

elements.text: That's a silly restriction on the parsing of the constraint. I would write it as f - g > 0, which is how I think it should be rewritten automatically. I hadn't thought about f /g - 1. That seems like a bad idea when g can be zero

messages.text:
Hi all, I’m giving a talk about the JuliaIntervals suite of packages on Tuesday. You can register here: <http://crm.math.ca/camp-nonlinear/#seminars>
It should also be available on YouTube later.

This is a talk aimed at people who are familiar with the basics of interval arithmetic. (See e.g. my JuliaCon 2020 workshop for an introduction.). I’ll discuss some recent work

elements.text: Hi all, I’m giving a talk about the JuliaIntervals suite of packages on Tuesday. You can register here:

It should also be available on YouTube later.

This is a talk aimed at people who are familiar with the basics of interval arithmetic. (See e.g. my JuliaCon 2020 workshop for an introduction.). I’ll discuss some recent work

messages.text:
It seems that both `IntervalConstraintProgramming` and `IntervalRootFinding` export `Contractor`, this makes the program crash if both package are imported. Should `IntervalConstraintProgramming` import `Contractor` from `IntervalRootFinding` and then re-export it?
```julia> using IntervalRootFinding, IntervalConstraintProgramming, ModelingToolkit

julia> @variables x y
(x, y)

julia> C = Contractor(x+y)
WARNING: both IntervalConstraintProgramming and IntervalRootFinding export "Contractor"; uses of it in module Main must be qualified
ERROR: UndefVarError: Contractor not defined
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope at REPL[4]:1```

elements.text: , this makes the program crash if both package are imported. Should

julia> using IntervalRootFinding, IntervalConstraintProgramming, ModelingToolkit

julia> @variables x y
(x, y)

julia> C = Contractor(x+y)
WARNING: both IntervalConstraintProgramming and IntervalRootFinding export "Contractor"; uses of it in module Main must be qualified
ERROR: UndefVarError: Contractor not defined
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope at REPL[4]:1

messages.text: Which program crashes?
Good question. That would be an OK temporary solution, I guess.

elements.text: Good question. That would be an OK temporary solution, I guess.
